messages.content:
You are a professional academic reference prediction expert. Your task is to predict the most likely references for a given academic paper based on its title, abstract, and retrieved relevant papers.

RETRIEVER INTERFACE:
- Input: paper title + abstract
- Output: {top_r} retrieved papers with title and abstract
- Format: List of dictionaries with 'title' and 'abstract' fields

REQUIREMENTS:
1. Analyze the paper's title and abstract to understand its research area and focus
2. Consider the retrieved papers as potential references (when available)
3. Generate a list of predicted reference titles that would be most relevant and likely to be cited
4. Provide reasoning for each prediction to prevent hallucination
5. Output format: JSON object with "titles" array and "reasoning" string
6. Generate exactly 56 most relevant reference titles (this should be at least 40 to cover all evaluation metrics)
7. Ensure titles are realistic and appropriate for the research area
8. Consider citation patterns in the field
9. CRITICAL: Each title must be unique - never repeat the same title multiple times

EXAMPLE:
Input:
Title: "Question Type Classification Methods Comparison"
Abstract: "The paper presents a comparative study of state-of-the-art approaches for question classification task: Logistic Regression, Convolutional Neural Networks (CNN), Long Short-Term Memory Network (LSTM) and Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks (QRNN). All models use pre-trained GLoVe word embeddings and trained on human-labeled data. The best accuracy is achieved using CNN model with five convolutional layers and various kernel sizes stacked in parallel, followed by one fully connected layer. The model reached 90.7% accuracy on TREC 10 test set."

Retrieved papers ({top_r}):
1. Title: Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification
   Abstract: We report on a series of experiments with convolutional neural networks trained on top of pre-trained word vectors for sentence-level classification tasks.

2. Title: Glove: Global vectors for word representation
   Abstract: We present a new global log-bilinear regression model that combines the advantages of the two major model families in the literature.

Output:
{
  "titles": [
    "Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification",
    "Glove: Global vectors for word representation",
    "Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks",
    "A Comparative Study of Neural Network Models for Sentence Classification",
    "Deep lstm based feature mapping for query classification"
  ],
  "reasoning": "Based on the paper's focus on question classification using neural networks, I predict these references because: 1) CNN paper is directly relevant to the convolutional approach used; 2) GloVe embeddings are mentioned as pre-trained features; 3) QRNN is one of the compared methods; 4) Comparative study papers are common in this field; 5) LSTM-based query classification is closely related to question classification. Additional references cover related neural network architectures, NLP applications, deep learning methodologies, optimization techniques, and advanced neural network methods that would be relevant for this research area."
}

Return JSON object only.

Paper Title: Symmetric Exponential Time Requires Near-Maximum Circuit Size

Paper Abstract: Abstract We show that there is a language in ¬ß2\E/1\S_{2}\E/_{1} (symmetric exponential time with one bit of advice) with circuit complexity at least 2n/nsuperscript2ùëõùëõ2^{n}/n. In particular, the above also implies the same near-maximum circuit lower bounds for the classes Œ£2‚Äã\EsubscriptŒ£2\E\Sigma_{2}\E, (Œ£2\E‚à©Œ†2\E)/1(\Sigma_{2}\E\cap\Pi_{2}\E)/_{1}, and ùñπùñØùñ§\NP/1\mathsf{ZPE}^{\NP}/_{1}. Previously, only ‚Äúhalf-exponential‚Äù circuit lower bounds for these complexity classes were known, and the smallest complexity class known to require exponential circuit complexity was Œî3‚Äã\E=\EŒ£2‚Äã¬∂subscriptŒî3\Esuperscript\EsubscriptŒ£2¬∂\Delta_{3}\E=\E^{\Sigma_{2}\P} (Miltersen, Vinodchandran, and Watanabe COCOON‚Äô99). Our circuit lower bounds are corollaries of an unconditional zero-error pseudodeterministic algorithm with an \NP\NP\NP oracle and one bit of advice (\FZPP\NP/1\FZPP^{\NP}/_{1}) that solves the range avoidance problem infinitely often. This algorithm also implies unconditional infinitely-often pseudodeterministic \FZPP\NP/1\FZPP^{\NP}/_{1} constructions for Ramsey graphs, rigid matrices, two-source extractors, linear codes, and KpolysuperscriptKpoly\mathrm{K}^{\mathrm{poly}}-random strings with nearly optimal parameters. Our proofs relativize. The two main technical ingredients are (1) Korten‚Äôs ¬∂\NPsuperscript¬∂\NP\P^{\NP} reduction from the range avoidance problem to constructing hard truth tables (FOCS‚Äô21), which was in turn inspired by a result of Je≈ô√°bek on provability in Bounded Arithmetic (Ann. Pure Appl. Log. 2004); and (2) the recent iterative win-win paradigm of Chen, Lu, Oliveira, Ren, and Santhanam (FOCS‚Äô23).

{retrieved_text}

Generate exactly 56 most likely reference titles for this paper. Focus on papers that are directly related to the research topic, provide foundational background, present similar methodologies, or address related problems.

CRITICAL: Each title must appear exactly once. Do not repeat any title.

IMPORTANT: You must respond with ONLY valid JSON in this exact format:
{
    "titles": [
        "Reference Title 1",
        "Reference Title 2",
        "Reference Title 3",
        "Reference Title 4",
        "Reference Title 56"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Explain why you chose these specific references based on the paper's title, abstract, and retrieved papers. This helps prevent hallucination and ensures relevance."
}

Do not include any text before or after the JSON. Do not include authors, venues, or years - only the paper titles. The reasoning field is required to explain your prediction logic.

{
    "titles": [
        "Oracles are subtle but not malicious",
        "Computational Complexity: A Modern Approach",
        "PRIMES is in ¬∂¬∂\\P",
        "Oracles and queries that are sufficient for exact learning",
        "Non-deterministic exponential time has two-prover interactive protocols",
        "\\BPP\\BPP\\BPP has subexponential time simulations unless ùñ§ùñ∑ùñØùñ≥ùñ®ùñ¨ùñ§ùñ§ùñ∑ùñØùñ≥ùñ®ùñ¨ùñ§{\\sf EXPTIME} has publishable proofs",
        "Nonrelativizing separations",
        "Qualitative relativizations of complexity classes",
        "Making hard problems harder",
        "¬ß2p‚äÜ\\ZPP\\NPsuperscriptsubscript¬ß2ùëùsuperscript\\ZPP\\NP\\S_{2}^{p}\\subseteq\\ZPP^{\\NP}",
        "More on \\BPP\\BPP\\BPP and the polynomial-time hierarchy",
        "Competing provers yield improved Karp‚ÄìLipton collapse results",
        "Polynomial-time pseudodeterministic construction of primes",
        "Relations and equivalences between circuit lower bounds and Karp‚ÄìLipton theorems",
        "Hardness vs randomness, revised: Uniform, non-black-box, and instance-wise",
        "Simple and fast derandomization from very hard functions: eliminating randomness at almost no cost",
        "Explicit two-source extractors and resilient functions",
        "Graph theory and probability",
        "On using oracles that compute values",
        "Reviewing bounds on the circuit size of the hardest functions",
        "Probabilistic search algorithms with unique answers and their cryptographic applications",
        "How to construct random functions",
        "Range avoidance for constant depth circuits: Hardness and algorithms",
        "Range avoidance for low-depth circuits and connections to pseudorandomness",
        "Computational complexity: a conceptual perspective",
        "Highly resilient correctors for polynomials",
        "Identifying an honest \\EXP\\NPsuperscript\\EXP\\NP\\EXP^{\\NP} oracle among many",
        "Bounded relativization",
        "Computing solutions uniquely collapses the polynomial hierarchy",
        "The power of natural properties as oracles",
        "In search of an easy witness: exponential time vs. probabilistic polynomial time",
        "¬∂=\\BPP¬∂\\BPP\\P=\\BPP if \\E\\E\\E requires exponential circuits: Derandomizing the XOR lemma",
        "Dual weak pigeonhole principle, Boolean complexity, and derandomization",
        "Circuit-size lower bounds and non-reducibility to sparse sets",
        "Circuit minimization problem",
        "Total functions in the polynomial hierarchy",
        "Some connections between nonuniform and uniform complexity classes",
        "The hardest explicit construction",
        "Tautologies from pseudo-random generators",
        "The complexity of optimization problems",
        "Graph nonisomorphism has subexponential size proofs unless the polynomial-time hierarchy collapses",
        "New collapse consequences of \\NP\\NP\\NP having small circuits",
        "Algebraic methods for interactive proof systems",
        "Two source extractors for asymptotically optimal entropy, and (many) more",
        "On the synthesis of switching circuits",
        "Super-polynomial versus half-exponential circuit size in the exponential hierarchy",
        "Hardness vs randomness",
        "Symmetric alternation captures \\BPP\\BPP\\BPP",
        "On the range avoidance problem for circuits",
        "Circuit lower bounds for Merlin‚ÄìArthur classes",
        "A taxonomy of complexity classes of functions",
        "The synthesis of two-terminal switching circuits",
        "Efficient Checking of Polynomials and Proofs and the Hardness of Approximation Problems, volume 1001 of Lecture Notes in Computer Science",
        "Graph-theoretic arguments in low-level complexity",
        "A note on the circuit complexity of \\PP\\PP\\PP",
        "On oracles and algorithmic methods for proving lower bounds"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Selected these 56 references because they represent foundational work and recent advances in Symmetric Exponential Time Requires Near-Maximum Circuit Size, providing essential background knowledge and methodological foundations relevant to this research."
}
